moves.1. d4: My usual d4 queens pawn opening.
moves.1... Nf6: black chooses an indian defence, an opening that is usually a waiting type opening, at least in my experience. Black wants to know what white is going to do next...
moves.2. c4: Book move, really, continuing along the lines of the indian defence
moves.4. a3: I play a3 in an attempt to trap the bishop. A possible line here is 4. a3 Ba5  5. b4 Bb6 and finally, c5 traps the bishop
moves.4... Bxc3+: Black plays along along a variation of the nimzo-indian. I personally like to see a move like this early in a game trading a bishop for a knight in a game that in most cases turns out to be fairly open where bishops have a slight advantage over knights...
moves.5. bxc3 c5: Still in opening book theory, I was actually surprised to see this move. Most players are not that schooled this deep in the Nimzo-indian (Samisch Variation). In fact, I have no idea what the response from white is supposed to be here.
moves.6. d5: We are finally out of opening theory here, as my own knowledge of this opening is limited, so I played d5 not wanting to trade one of my central pawns for one of black's flankers.
moves.7... h6: I like to see this move, really, as it weakens the king side slightly...
moves.8. Bh4: Maintaining the pin and hoping for perhaps g5, a further weakening of BLack's kingside. Makes the previous move (h6) seem a bit silly...
moves.8... d6: Not sure why black doesn't want to play exd5 to free up his bishop....
moves.9. Nf3 Nbd7 10. e3 b6 11. Bd3 exd5: We finally see exd5, but Black still has his bishop trapped...
moves.12. cxd5 Bb7 13. c4: Now that the bishop has developed, I try to play to limit the newly developed bishop's mobility
moves.13... Ne5: I was glad to see this move as after the trade on e5,  I end up with a solid pawn center, a passed d pawn, and a stronger stranglehold on Black's white-squared bishop...
moves.14. Nxe5 dxe5 15. e4 Qd6 16. a4: played to stop a possible ... b5, which I dont want to see as it would undermine my strong center
moves.16... Bc8 17. O-O Bd7: good move by black here...puts my rook on pawn guard duty for a while...
moves.18. Qd2: preparing for the central pawn break...f4
moves.18... Ne8 19. f4 Nc7 20. fxe5 Qxe5 21. B: trying to take advantage of a skewer here on the undefended knight on c7...
moves.21... Qd4+: Black's only real response to stop Bxc7...
moves.22. Bf2 Qf6: Moves right into a discovered attack possiblity...
moves.23. Bg3: hoping again for the knight on c7, this time with the discovered attack on Black's queen...
moves.23... Qd8: Not sure I would have chosen this move, but I was glad to see Blacks's queen in such an isolated position and tied to the defence of a knight
moves.24. Qf4: obvious threat of winning the knight on c7 with a queen trade
moves.25. Rf2: preparing for an eventual pile up of my rooks on the F file...
moves.25... Ne8: Cuts off the defence of the rook...a move I am going to try to take advantage of...
moves.26... f6: Love to see Black further weakening his king position...
moves.27. Qe4: not sure why I played this, besids the simple threat of Qh7+. Takes me a move or so to realize that my e pawn is perfectly safe.
moves.27... f5 28. Qf4 g5: Black cant stand that queen, apparently, but this move further opens the kingside
moves.29. Qf3 f4: It is at this point I realize my error a few moves ago and see that Black cannot capture the Bishop with out mate to follow
moves.30. e6: My bishop is safe...I play e6 to trap Black's bishop instead...
moves.30... fxg3: The move that made my day, black doesn't see the mate threat...
